Nick's Blog

Code Repositories

25 March 2006

One thing that CPAN doesn't offer, and I seriously wish they did, is repository access. If once you created a module and uploaded it to CPAN it would be sooo wonderful if you could also host your code and development on CPAN as well via a subversion or cvs repository.

Until then we have other options. I've never been a fan of using a local subversion repository because if my laptop breaks or gets stolen, then it is most likely lost forever. I really don't like SourceForge either, but Tigris isn't bad at all.

Not too long ago SixApart started code.sixapart.com small niche of open source projects started by people who work at sixapart. Its a real nice concept actually. It is nothing terribly fancy or complex, but a simple subversion repository and a place to talk about your project.

I've put up a few of my projects up already: Audio::AMR::Decode, WWW::NameGen, WWW::Yahoo::KeywordExtractor and SenseNet.

The first three are already on cpan, see http://search.cpan.org/~/sock, but the last is still in development. Its getting big enough to need its own project blog, so sooner or later I'll put one up for it.
